The Guidance System for a compassionate Society
The Family GPs
Tell Me More

One family

In 1972 Arnold Toynbee, the historian of world civilizations, warned: "Mankind is surely going to destroy itself unless it succeeds in growing together into something like a single family." World events have been continually changing since then, but even in the shocks of natural or human disasters, or the dislocations of national and global turmoil, photographs of planet Earth from above should always remind us that all 8 billion of us who live here are all members of one family.

Harmony

Fathers And Mothers, Infants, eLders, and Youth (FAMILY) believes that our body, soul, mind, and spirit, joined together, are the embodiment of the way society is structured and the way that it should function. Society's systems should always interact in harmony with each other for the common good, as do the systems of our bodies, whose organ systems - nervous, circulatory, digestive, and all others - are interconnected and interdependent. When we are healthy, all our organ systems interact in harmony to maintain our well-being. And so it should also be with society.

Model

A society is healthy only to the degree to which all systems – political, healthcare, education, economic, justice, and all others, including the infrastructure that it builds and maintains - are aligned by its moral compass - Truth. Thus aligned, the systems will interact in harmony for the well-being of all members, starting with the babies and their families. But our society is critically ill with multi-system failure! Its systems are not working together for the well-being of all of us as they should. Some are doing very well for themselves while others can't breathe!

Diagnosis and Mission

Our Diagnosis - Tunnel Vision: A dark veil prevents us from seeing that we are all members of one family. What must we do? Lift the veil where you are! When the veil is lifted, we can envision Mother Earth clearly, with light from Above. FAMILY must help all of us to learn new ways to create compassionate communities by developing effective "wrap-around" support systems (muscle system) for all of us, starting with our babies and their families. Developing a strong Social Infrastructure will realign society's systems so they will function as they should - like a wholesome family.

Dedicated Team

Always help each other as though we are all members of one family - because we are.

Dr. Harold May

FAMILY Founder.

Harold May was born in Peekskill, NY, in 1926. He entered Harvard College in 1944 as part of the accelerated program during World War II and entered the Air Corps in 1945, becoming part of the Tuskegee Airmen program. After the war, Dr. May returned to Harvard, and entered Harvard Medical School in 1947. After medical school, Dr. May completed a surgical residency at Massachusetts General Hospital, which was interrupted by eye surgery. During his convalescence, he traveled to Haiti and, after his residency, returned to Haiti, where he worked at the Albert Schweitzer Hospital. He also served as Director of Community Health at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital, Medical Director of the Wrentham Developmental Center, and as Founder of FAMILY, Inc., a non-profit which creates secure and nurturing environments of mutual supports in which all children and families can thrive.

  • Interest: Primary Care, Community Health, Medical Education
  • LinkedIn: Dr. Harold May

Bill Walczak

Passionate Community Leader, Health Advocate and FAMILY Board Member.

Bill is most associated with the re-development of the Codman Square area of Boston, a multi-cultural community which foundered in the 1970s and became an area known for racial unrest and economic disintegration. Bill was founding president and CEO of the Codman Square Health Center, a major factor in the regeneration of the community, was founding president of Codman Academy Charter School, and most recently was CEO of the South End Community Health Center in Boston where he developed a joint medical residency in psychiatry and family medicine. He has been a President and/or CEO of health care organizations for 42 years. He is currently retired from regular employment and writes columns for his community newspaper, The Dorchester Reporter.

Bill is chair of the Board of Trustees of Bunker Hill Community College, and chair of the Massachusetts Business Alliance for Education. He is a trustee of the Massachusetts Board of Higher Education, representing community colleges. He was founding president of the Massachusetts Nonprofit Network, a founder of the Edward Kennedy Health Careers Academy, a founder of the Center for Community Health, Education, Research and Service at Northeastern University, and founding president of Boston HealthNet. He is a past President of the UMass/Boston Alumni Association. He serves on the boards of the Rappaport Center at Boston College Law School, FAMILY, Daily Table, HealthWorks at Codman, The American City Coalition, the Pat Cooke Fund, the Trustees Group, and Massachusetts State College Building Authority. Bill is the elected president of the Columbia-Savin Hill Civic Association, representing a large part of the Dorchester neighborhood. p>

Bill served on both Governors Deval Patrick's and Charlie Baker's Health Care Transition Committees, and on Acting Mayor Kim Janey's Transition Committee. He is also co-director of the Pat Cook Fund, which supports curriculum development around the environment. Bill has worked on community regeneration efforts in a number of countries around the world. He was involved with the Northern Irish peace process for over a decade and led a program in post-apartheid South Africa that included support of patients with HIV, support of a women's empowerment center, built a technology center for a school and developed a micro-enterprise project. He helped to develop a family medicine program for the country of Vietnam. Bill has received numerous awards for his work and ideas.

  • Interest: Community Development, Health Care, Education
  • LinkedIn: Bill Walczak

David Mark, MD

David Mark is a primary care physician and the founder and CEO of One Health, a federally qualified health center serving rural communities in rural Montana and Wyoming. With a mission to improve the wellbeing of the whole community by providing accessible, high-quality healthcare, One Health deploys a model that emulates the FAMILY concept by integrating medical, behavioral health, pharmacy, and dental care into a seamless experience for patients.

David received his undergraduate degree from Yale University and pursued medical education at the Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology. He completed residency training in Internal Medicine and Pediatrics at the Brigham and Women's Hospital, Massachusetts General Hospital, and Children's Hospital in Boston. He serves on the Montana Primary Care Association board of directors and on the board of Big Sky Care Connect, Montana's Health Information Exchange. He lives in Hardin, MT, and enjoys spending time with his wife and three children.

  • Interests: Rural Health, Integrated Care, Health IT
  • LinkedIn: David Mark, MD

Kristina Wile

Managing Partner, Systems Thinking Collaborative

Kris Wile is a founding partner at the Systems Thinking Collaborative. She is a facilitator, educator and consultant in the areas of systems thinking, system dynamics, and systems change. She has twenty years of experience working with a broad range of clients in public and private sectors to develop and use models to motivate and inform strategic planning and implementation. Kris received an MS degree in System Dynamics and Operations at the MIT Sloan School of Management in 1994. While there, her research focused on the dynamics of organizational change and business ethics. She also has a BS in Electronics and Computer Engineering, and seven years of experience in high tech as a systems engineer and project manager.

Highlights: More than 25 years of business experience in a range of industries (consumer and industrial electronics, consulting, education, oil production and transport, environment, and public health) and functional areas (engineering, manufacturing, consulting, operations, C-Suite, and marketing). Skilled facilitator with a well-developed methodology for collaborative systemic problem solving, strategy development, and scenario planning Collaborative problem solver with an emphasis on establishing widespread buy-in and supporting ongoing organizational learning. Project manager supporting teams to achieve goals and produce deliverables for long term projects in research, product development, and service delivery.

  • Interests: Systems Thinking, Organizational Change, Facilitation
  • LinkedIn: Kristina Wile

Charles F O'Connell

Lawyer, Adjunct Professor, Panelist.

Charles F. O'Connell is the Managing Partner of the Boston law firm Taylor, Ganson & Perrin, LLP. Mr. O'Connell concentrates in taxation, estate planning, trust and estate administration, family business planning and family office administration for domestic, cross border and international clients. Mr. O'Connell serves as the Trustee of diverse types of trusts. Mr. O'Connell served as an arbitrator for the National Association of Securities Dealers and the New York Stock Exchange.

Mr. O'Connell is the author of the book “Compensating United States Employees Abroad” which was published as Volume Four of the International Business Portfolios by the Matthew Bender and Company division of the Times Mirror Company. Mr. O'Connell was also a contributing author to Bender's Federal Tax Service. Mr. O'Connell served as an Adjunct Professor of Law at Suffolk University Law School for seven years where he taught courses on the legal aspects of providing trust and investment services as well as the taxation of qualified retirement plans.

Mr. O'Connell has also served as a panel member for continuing legal education sponsored by the American Bar Association and Suffolk University Law School. Mr. O'Connell presented a paper entitled “The Lawyer as Trustee” at the 1999 American Bar Association Annual Meeting. Mr. O'Connell is a magna cum laude graduate (BS) of Boston College, a cum laude graduate (JD) of Suffolk University Law School and has a law degree (LLB) from Cambridge University, Cambridge, England.

Mr. O'Connell is admitted to law practice in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, the US District Court for the District of Massachusetts, the US Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, the Supreme Court of the United States and the United States Tax Court. Mr. O'Connell is a Member of the Boston and Massachusetts Bar Associations and a full Member of the Society of Trust and Estate Practitioners holding the Trust and Estate Practitioner designation.

  • Interests: Taxation, Estate Planning, Trust Administration
  • Profile: Charles F O'Connell

Darrell LeMar

Program Coordination and Management, Strategic Partnerships/Planning

Darrell LeMar is a compassionate and dedicated professional with well over 13 years of experience with educating and advocating for a better quality of living for students and individuals in the community. Creative problem-solver to develop solutions to complex situations in sensitive settings. Excellent program and people management to ensure funds are used most effectively in non-profit, academic, and cooperate environments to ensure goals are met with data-driven results.

Darrell demonstrated outstanding interpersonal and communication abilities to collaborate with the community, partners, staff, and leadership to reach consensus to support the organization's objective. Fluent in English and Spanish to meet the needs of a diverse population.

  • Interests: Program Coordination and Management, Strategic Partnerships/Planning
  • LinkedIn: Darrell LeMar

Leonard M. Lee

Public Health and Education, Political Strategy, Youth Development and Violence Prevention.

Leonard M. Lee has more than 30 years leading non-profit, community-based organizations, including developing strategies and creating high-impact programs for political campaigns and municipal and state programs, most notably in the public health arena with a focus on youth development and prevention of violence. A high achiever who consistently exceeds organizational goals and objectives with creative and innovative problem solving, complemented by strong coalition building among political and community leaders and their constituents.

Leonard is a highly motivated self-starter who favors fast-paced, demanding grass-roots environments and provides a management style that grows and maintains lasting community relationships by providing outstanding service and conscientious follow-up. A strategic planner who brings strong analytical skills and negotiation-mediation expertise to deliver the right requirements on time to any project. Considered the “Go-To Guy” and a content expert in organizational development, operational efficiency, and performance management.

  • Interests: Community Development, Public Health, Youth Programs
  • LinkedIn: Leonard M. Lee

Riché C. Zamor, Sr.

Retired, Public Health Administrator.

Riché C. Zamor, Sr. has over twenty-five years of progressively responsible experience in the development and management of community health promotion and education programs. Demonstrated skills in management planning, health care policy, program development, negotiation and problem solving. Ability to manage and supervise complex programs through teamwork. Solid grounding in data analysis and substantive knowledge of public health issues. Committed to capacity building of individuals, organizations and communities as a core development approach.

Riché is an institution builder with strong team building, negotiation, and interpersonal communications skills. Experience in international public health, effective community-level responses to complex health challenges, and knowledge of the opportunities and challenges in working with community-based organizations. Solid project management skills, experience working with international and national/community networks, organizational capacity development and monitoring and evaluation experience; and possess strong communication, planning and organizing skills. Strongly committed to excellence in multicultural environment that fosters diversity. Ability to use technology effectively in teaching and learning, ability to work collaboratively, and a commitment to higher education.

  • Interests: Public Health Administration, Community Health, Program Development
  • LinkedIn: Riché C. Zamor, Sr.

Aggie May

FAMILY - Accountant, Treasurer, Steady Hands

Aggie was born in Canada and grew up on a farm in Abbotsford, a city in the Fraser Valley of British Columbia. She was raised in the Mennonite community, a Protestant denomination known for sending volunteers around the world to support agricultural, educational, medical, and humanitarian work in twenty‑seven countries — including Haiti.

In August 1959, Aggie left Canada and arrived in Deschapelles, Haiti, to work at Hôpital Albert Schweitzer. The following January, she met a young doctor named Hal May, who had recently arrived from the United States. Aggie and Hal soon married and spent nearly eleven years in Haiti serving at the Schweitzer Hospital. Their three daughters were born there. Their first daughter, born with significant medical challenges, passed away at a very young age and was laid to rest in Haiti.

In 1970, the May family left Haiti and settled in the Boston area. Aggie devoted herself to raising her family while also taking on temporary office positions as Dr. May worked at Brigham and Women's Hospital. During their years in Boston, Aggie worked alongside Dr. May in a variety of nonprofit initiatives, including FAMILY. Over the decades, she served in many roles — accountant, treasurer, and steadfast supporter — always guided by her commitment to service.

Aggie and Dr. May's dedication to helping others is reflected in the paths their daughters have chosen. Allison is a physician in the Boston area who has spent more than twenty‑two years caring for the homeless community. Jeannette is a public health educator, and Margie, the youngest, is a dietitian.

  • Interests: Community Support, Administration

Hope Haslam Straughan

Clinical Associate Professor of Social Work, Coordinator.

Hope Haslam Straughan is the coordinator for the dual-degree Master of Social Work/Master of Theology Studies at Boston University. “I completed my MSW studies at a seminary in which I also received a certificate in Theology,” she explains. “In this way, my understanding of the underlying philosophies of social work were coupled with a deeper understanding of the interconnectedness of people and the call to care for one another—especially the vulnerable among us.”

Prior to joining the BUSSW faculty in June 2018, Haslam Straughan served as dean for the School of Social Work, Leadership, and Youth Advocacy at Wheelock College. Her research interests include spirituality within social work practice, justice-based social work, child welfare, and foster care and adoption, with a particular focus on transracial adoption. Haslam Straughan is the author of Parenting in Transracial Adoption: Real Questions and Real Answers (Praeger, 2016). Forced to choose: BSW students' experiences of a higher education merger (Journal of Social Work Education, 2023), Parental understandings of cultural difference: A study of transracially adopting couples (Families in Society, 2025), and Sustainable social work practice through ritual (Journal of Religion and Spirituality, 2025).

Haslam Straughan is also a volunteer foster care case reviewer for the Massachusetts Department of Children and Families, serves on the board of FAMILY, Inc., and Key, Inc., and reviews manuscripts for the NACSW Journal, Christianity and Social Work, as well as Simmons University's journal, Field Education.

  • Interests: Social Work Education, Child Welfare, Transracial Adoption
  • LinkedIn: Hope Haslam Straughan

Emanus Simeon

DevOps Engineer / Tech Hobbyist / STEM Volunteer / Adjunct Professor

Emanus Simeon is a Principal DevOps Engineer at PDSVISION and an Adjunct Professor at Franklin Cummings Tech in Boston. He brings a rich and diverse background spanning IT, Cloud Computing, Augmented and Virtual Reality (AR/VR), Desktop Publishing, and STEM education.

Emanus holds a master's in software engineering from Brandeis University, a bachelor's degree in computer science from Wentworth Institute of Technology, and an associate degree in Electronic Engineering Technology from Franklin Cummings Tech. His academic foundation reflects a lifelong commitment to learning, innovation, and technical excellence.

Born in Haiti, Emanus immigrated to the United States in the mid 1980s, spending several years in different cities in Massachusetts and Florida before ultimately returning to the Boston area, where he now resides. He has been married to his wife, Michaelle, for over 31 years, and together they are the proud parents of four young adult sons: Emanuel, Michael, Samuel, and Nathanael. Guided by his faith, Emanus views service as a lifelong calling and a core expression of his beliefs.

Emanus serves on the Board of ShelterBox USA, an organization dedicated to ensuring no family is left without shelter after disaster. He is also a board member of FAMILY, an NGO supporting initiatives in Haiti, Boston, Montana, and Tuskegee University. His passion for advancing science and technology extends to his active support of the FIRST Robotics Competition in Haiti through First Lego League Haiti (FEDUDEVH).

  • Interests: Technology, Education, Volunteering
  • LinkedIN: Emanus Simeon

Joel Theodat

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur.

Born in Haiti, Joel Theodat came to the United States as a young man to continue his studies. He earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Philosophy from Suffolk University in 1980 and a Master of Science degree in Philosophy from Boston College in 1984. For 22 years, Joel worked as a teacher and Bilingual Program Director at West Roxbury High School and at Hyde Park High in Boston, MA. Dealing mostly with Haitian youngsters who recently migrated to the United States, Joel helped them adjust to the American culture while maintaining and honoring their Haitian culture.

In 2006, his passion and love for Haiti took him back to Haiti as Executive Director of a non-profit organization providing education and health care to the people in the Bourdon area of Port-au-Prince. Joel currently teaches Haitian Creole to health care providers and others at the University of Massachusetts. His heart is fully committed to help eradicate illiteracy and denounce injustice wherever it may be. Working with Greening Haiti Fund is another extension of his efforts to help the people of Haiti.

Dedicated school and community based leader with 25+ years of extensive experience managing all facets of school system needs including: curriculum, leadership and workforce development, organizational change management, employee relations, compensation and benefits strategies. International experiences.

"Life is a puzzle. Imagine if we work together to find the right pieces and its meaning." Joel Theodat

  • Interests: Leadership, Cultural Development, Education, Volunteering
  • LinkedIN: Joel Theodat
